The Helena Chemical Company (Helena) Fairview, IL Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act 112 (r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CFR Part 68. Standards codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration at 29 CFR 1910.119 are not applicable to the operations at this facility because the facility is operated as a retail operation and is exempt from the OSHA standards.  However, the OSHA standards at 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, are applicable and are included in the Risk Management Program (RMPr) document that is implemented by this Facility.



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the Fairview, IL Facility located less than one mile west of Fairview, IL at an intersection along Carter Street and Bottom Road in Fairview, IL.  The physical address to the Facility is 1285 West Carter Street, Fairview, IL 61432.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Fairview, IL Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Fairview, IL Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release (even though a release is unlikely) will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



Helena is submitting this as a 5-year update.  All relevant sections for a Program 2 RMP Facility have been reviewed and/or updated.  The updates are reflected in both the EPA RMP Submit report and the Facility Risk Management Plan Program Document (RMPr).



FACILITY



The Fairview, IL Facility is a retail agricultural chemical facility and operates one (1) covered process that includes Storage and Handling of anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is transported to the Facility via a commercial tanker truck (9,600 gallon) and then transferred t

o one (1) 12,000-gallon stationary storage tank and two (2) 8,000-gallon stationary storage tanks.  The commercial tanker truck operator (Vendor/Contractor) performs these transfer operations.  



Helena stores the anhydrous ammonia in the on-site stationary storage tanks and then transfers the anhydrous ammonia from the storage tank to nurse tanks at point of retail sale to the end user (e.g. the farmer).  This Facility owns and operates (26) 1,000-gallon nurse tanks.  Helena performs this operation in accordance with its RMPr accident prevention program.  









OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for the single covered process that is operated at this Facility.  The covered process includes anhydrous ammonia Storage and Handling.  The worst case scenario release for the Retail Facility assumes that all the contents in the largest single storage tank are released.  For this Facility, the largest vessel is a 12,000-gallon stationary storage tank.  The release was modeled as if the ammonia tank was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario was also completed for the storage and handling covered process.  The alternative release for the Storage and Handling assumes a 30-second release from a ruptured 3-inch transfer hose caused by an impact from a vehicle or some other source on the liquid ammonia transfer hose during a loading or unloading operation.  Although this event is classified as an alternative scenario, even an accident of this type is unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment (i.e. back flow check valve and excess flow valves) and operating procedures that Helena uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Operations Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Operations Manager

is assisted by other Helena staff, as directed.  The Operations Manager is responsible for ensuring that Helena Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Prevention Program which includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigations, and Emergency Contingency Plans.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Helena's Fairview, IL Facility is a non-responding facility. Helena has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the Fairview, IL Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by Helena Chemical Company at the Fairview, IL Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Fairview, IL Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Fulton County LEPC and the Fairview Volunteer Fire Department.  



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 7 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Fairview, IL Facility.
